issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the type of the Animal.name attribute: the UML diagram shows the attribute as 'name: String' while the textual instructions (Part 1) explicitly require using StringBuilder for the name attribute. This conflicting guidance can confuse students about which type they should use when implementing Animal, its constructor, and getter/setter.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement consistent: either change the UML diagram to show 'name: StringBuilder' (if you want students to use StringBuilder) or remove/adjust the textual instruction to use String. Prefer updating the UML to 'name: StringBuilder' if the pedagogical intent is to require StringBuilder for the name field.

issues.description: The reference solution implements Animal.name as a String (private String name; constructor, getter, and setter use String), which contradicts the problem statement's explicit instruction to use StringBuilder for the name attribute. This mismatch between specification and solution may confuse students about the intended implementation and expectations.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem specification: change Animal.name to a StringBuilder, update the constructor to accept/initialize a StringBuilder (or accept a String and wrap it into a new StringBuilder), and adjust the getter/setter signatures/behavior accordingly. Alternatively, if using String is acceptable, revise the problem statement to remove the StringBuilder requirement.
